hook.text: A car dealer says $40,000. You counter with $35,000 and feel clever. But you just got anchored.

buildup.text: Anchoring means the first number you hear disproportionately shapes every number after it.

discovery.text: Tversky and Kahneman proved it: even random numbers on a spinning wheel shifted people's estimates.

twist.text: Knowing about anchoring doesn't make you immune. The bias works even when you know it's happening.

climax.text: Restaurants put a $300 wine on the menu so the $80 bottle feels like a bargain.

punchline.text: Whoever sets the first number controls the negotiation.

quiz.question: What is anchoring bias?
options: The first number heard disproportionately shapes subsequent judgments
People always choose the middle option
Larger numbers are always more persuasive

topics.title: Confirmation Bias: Seeing What You Expect

hook.text: You think your product is great. So you read every positive review and skip the negative ones.

buildup.text: Confirmation bias means we seek evidence that supports what we already believe.

discovery.text: Peter Wason's card experiment showed people test rules by looking for confirming cases, not disconfirming ones.

twist.text: Scientists are supposed to be objective. Studies show they interpret ambiguous data to match their hypothesis.

climax.text: The antidote: actively seek reasons you might be wrong. Ask 'What would change my mind?'

punchline.text: We don't see the world as it is. We see it as we are.

quiz.question: What is confirmation bias?
options: Seeking evidence that supports existing beliefs
Always agreeing with authority figures
Being overly confident in your abilities

hook.text: A man robbed banks in broad daylight, convinced lemon juice made his face invisible to cameras.

buildup.text: Dunning and Kruger found that people with low ability dramatically overestimate their competence.

discovery.text: The catch: the skills needed to be good at something are the same skills needed to judge quality.

twist.text: Meanwhile, experts tend to underestimate themselves â€” they assume everyone knows what they know.

climax.text: The loudest voice in a meeting is often the least informed. Confidence isn't a proxy for competence.

punchline.text: The less you know, the more you think you know.

quiz.question: What does the Dunning-Kruger effect describe?
options: Low-ability individuals overestimate their competence
Experts always know how skilled they are
Intelligence decreases with age

topics.title: Availability Bias: What Comes to Mind First

hook.text: After seeing a plane crash on the news, you drive instead of fly. But driving is 100x more dangerous.

buildup.text: Availability bias means we judge frequency by how easily examples come to mind.

discovery.text: Vivid, recent, or emotional events feel more common than they are. Shark attacks feel frequent; they're rare.

twist.text: Media amplifies this. News covers dramatic events, not everyday risks, warping our sense of probability.

climax.text: Investors panic-sell after a crash and miss recoveries. The vivid memory overrides the base rate.

punchline.text: What's memorable isn't what's most likely.

quiz.question: Why do people overestimate the risk of shark attacks?
options: Vivid media coverage makes them seem more common
Shark attacks are actually very common
People have innate fear of water

hook.text: Apple releases a good phone. Suddenly people assume Apple's laptops, watches, and earbuds must be great too.

buildup.text: The halo effect means one positive trait makes us assume everything else is equally positive.

discovery.text: Phil Rosenzweig found that business books attribute success to culture and leadership â€” only after the stock rises.

twist.text: When the stock drops, the same company's culture is called toxic. Nothing changed except the share price.

climax.text: Interviewers who like a candidate's smile unconsciously rate their answers as smarter.

punchline.text: One good impression colors everything. So does one bad one.

quiz.question: What is the halo effect?
options: One positive impression makes us assume other traits are also positive
Successful companies always have great culture
Beautiful products always perform better

hook.text: In WWII, engineers studied bullet holes on returning planes. Abraham Wald said: armor the places with no holes.

buildup.text: Survivorship bias means we study successes and ignore the failures we never see.

discovery.text: The planes with holes in those other spots never came back. The data was missing, not absent.

twist.text: Business books study successful founders, ignoring thousands who did the same things and failed.

climax.text: Steve Jobs dropped out of college and succeeded. Millions dropped out and you'll never hear of them.

punchline.text: Don't copy survivors. Study what killed everyone else.

quiz.question: What did Abraham Wald recommend about the planes?
options: Armor the areas without bullet holes â€” those planes didn't survive
Add more armor everywhere equally
Remove armor to make planes lighter

hook.text: A store displayed 24 jams. Another displayed 6. The small display sold 10x more jam.

buildup.text: Sheena Iyengar proved that too many options paralyze people instead of empowering them.

discovery.text: When overwhelmed, we default to choosing nothing. The brain's shortcut for complexity is avoidance.

twist.text: More options feel better â€” customers say they want choice â€” but they actually buy less.

climax.text: Successful menus, apps, and stores curate ruthlessly. They remove options to increase action.

punchline.text: More choice doesn't mean more freedom. Often it means more paralysis.

quiz.question: What did Iyengar's jam experiment show?
options: Fewer options led to more purchases
More options led to more purchases
The type of jam mattered most

topics.title: Default Effects: The Power of Pre-Selection

hook.text: Germany's organ donor rate is 12%. Austria's is 99%. The difference? One checkbox on a form.

buildup.text: In Germany you opt in. In Austria you opt out. Most people just accept the default.

discovery.text: Defaults work because changing requires effort, and humans are wired to avoid unnecessary effort.

twist.text: Software companies know this. Default settings shape behavior more than any feature announcement.

climax.text: Auto-enrolling employees in 401(k) plans doubled participation. Same plan, different default.

punchline.text: The default is the most powerful design choice you'll make.

quiz.question: Why does Austria have a 99% organ donor rate?
options: Citizens are opted in by default and must choose to opt out
A massive public awareness campaign
Financial incentives for donors

hook.text: '90% fat-free' and '10% fat' are the same thing. But one sells dramatically better.

buildup.text: Framing means how information is presented changes how people respond to it.

discovery.text: Tversky and Kahneman showed doctors chose differently for the same surgery based on survival vs. death framing.

twist.text: Rational people shouldn't be swayed by wording. But we're not rational. We're human.

climax.text: Politicians frame the same tax as 'relief' or 'cut' depending on their goal. Same policy, different emotion.

punchline.text: It's not what you say. It's the frame you put around it.

quiz.question: What does framing effect mean?
options: How information is presented changes how people respond
People always choose the first option presented
Visual design matters more than content

hook.text: The Economist offered: web-only $59, print-only $125, print+web $125. The middle option looks absurd.

buildup.text: That absurd option is the decoy. It exists only to make the combo look like a steal.

discovery.text: Without the decoy, most people chose web-only. With it, most chose the expensive combo.

twist.text: Nobody picks the decoy. Its job is to make another option look comparatively better.

climax.text: SaaS companies use three-tier pricing for this reason. The middle tier is often the decoy.

punchline.text: The option nobody picks is the one doing all the work.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of a decoy option in pricing?
options: To make another option seem more attractive by comparison
To attract budget-conscious buyers
To increase the number of options available

hook.text: You spend three hours comparing every phone online. Your friend buys the first one that's 'good enough.'

buildup.text: Maximizers seek the best option. Satisficers pick the first option that meets their criteria.

discovery.text: Barry Schwartz found maximizers get objectively better outcomes â€” but feel worse about them.

twist.text: More options make maximizers miserable. They can never be sure they didn't miss something better.

climax.text: Satisficers report higher life satisfaction. 'Good enough' turns out to feel better than 'optimal.'

punchline.text: Perfect is the enemy of happy.

quiz.question: What did Barry Schwartz find about maximizers?
options: They get better outcomes but feel worse about their choices
They always make the best decisions
They are happier than satisficers

topics.title: Loss Aversion: Losses Hurt Twice as Much

hook.text: Losing $100 hurts more than finding $100 feels good. About twice as much, actually.

buildup.text: Kahneman and Tversky proved we feel losses roughly twice as intensely as equivalent gains.

discovery.text: This is why free trials work so well. Once you have something, losing it feels terrible.

twist.text: Companies exploit this with 'limited time offers.' The fear of missing out is a fear of loss.

climax.text: Investors hold losing stocks too long, hoping to avoid locking in a loss. The pain of selling is too great.

punchline.text: We don't play to win. We play not to lose.

quiz.question: How much more intensely do people feel losses vs. gains?
options: About twice as much
About five times as much
About the same

hook.text: Give someone a coffee mug. Then offer to buy it back. They demand twice what they'd pay for it.

buildup.text: The endowment effect means owning something makes you value it more than before you owned it.

discovery.text: Thaler demonstrated this in experiments: sellers consistently priced items higher than buyers offered.

twist.text: This isn't about sentimental value. It happens with random items people received minutes earlier.

climax.text: Real estate agents use this: once buyers imagine living in a home, they've mentally claimed ownership.

punchline.text: Owning it changes how you see it. Always.

quiz.question: What is the endowment effect?
options: People value things more once they own them
People prefer gifts over purchases
Older items are always more valuable

topics.title: Prospect Theory: How We Weigh Outcomes

hook.text: Would you rather have $900 for sure or a 90% chance of $1,000? Most choose the sure thing.

buildup.text: Prospect theory says we evaluate outcomes relative to a reference point, not in absolute terms.

discovery.text: We're risk-averse with gains and risk-seeking with losses. Facing a sure loss, we gamble to avoid it.

twist.text: This explains why people buy lottery tickets and insurance simultaneously â€” irrational by classical economics.

climax.text: Kahneman won the Nobel Prize for this. It rewrote how economists think about human decision-making.

punchline.text: We don't calculate value. We feel it, relative to where we stand.

quiz.question: What does prospect theory say about how we treat losses?
options: We become risk-seeking to avoid a certain loss
We always avoid risk regardless of the situation
We treat gains and losses identically

hook.text: You paid $200 for concert tickets. It's raining. You're sick. You go anyway because you already paid.

buildup.text: The sunk cost fallacy means letting past spending influence future decisions it shouldn't affect.

discovery.text: Rationally, the money is gone either way. The only question is: will going make you happy now?

twist.text: Companies do this at massive scale. Projects get more funding because they've already spent millions.

climax.text: The Concorde jet kept flying for decades at a loss because governments wouldn't admit the investment failed.

punchline.text: What you've already spent shouldn't decide what you do next.

quiz.question: Why is the Concorde jet an example of sunk cost fallacy?
options: Governments kept funding it because of prior investment, not future viability
It was a profitable project that was cancelled too early
It was the fastest commercial plane ever built

hook.text: People prefer eliminating one small risk entirely over reducing a large risk by a bigger amount.

buildup.text: Zero-risk bias means we love certainty. Reducing risk from 5% to 0% feels better than 50% to 20%.

discovery.text: Governments spend billions removing tiny risks completely while ignoring larger, deadlier ones.

twist.text: The math says reduce the bigger risk. But our brains crave the comfort of 'zero.'

climax.text: Companies sell 'zero-risk' warranties on cheap electronics. Customers pay $30 to insure a $50 toaster.

punchline.text: We overpay for zero because certainty is addictive.

quiz.question: What is zero-risk bias?
options: Preferring total elimination of a small risk over larger reduction of a bigger risk
Avoiding all risky decisions entirely
Taking maximum risk for maximum reward

hook.text: A restaurant has a line out the door. The one next door is empty. You join the line without checking the menu.

buildup.text: Herding means copying what others do, especially when we're uncertain about the right choice.

discovery.text: Information cascades explain it: if enough people choose A, latecomers assume A must be right.

twist.text: Herding can be rational individually but catastrophic collectively â€” like a stock market bubble.

climax.text: Everyone bought real estate in 2006 because everyone else was. The herd ran off a cliff together.

punchline.text: When everyone agrees, nobody's thinking.

quiz.question: What triggers herding behavior?
options: Uncertainty makes us copy others' choices
People always prefer popular options
Crowds are usually right about everything

hook.text: 'Join 10 million happy customers.' You've seen this line everywhere. It works every time.

buildup.text: Social proof means we look to others' behavior as evidence of the right choice.

discovery.text: Robert Cialdini proved it: hotel towel reuse went up 26% when signs said 'most guests reuse their towels.'

twist.text: Negative social proof backfires. 'Millions evade taxes' actually increased tax evasion.

climax.text: Reviews, testimonials, and user counts all exploit this. We trust the crowd more than the brand.

punchline.text: Show people what others are doing. They'll follow.

quiz.question: Why can negative social proof backfire?
options: Highlighting bad behavior normalizes it
People don't read negative messages
Negative framing always reduces sales

hook.text: Bitcoin hit $20,000 and your taxi driver started buying. That's the bandwagon effect in action.

buildup.text: The bandwagon effect means adoption accelerates simply because more people are already adopting.

discovery.text: In markets, rising prices attract buyers, which raises prices further. Fundamentals stop mattering.

twist.text: Every bubble follows this pattern. The last buyers pay the highest price for the worst returns.

climax.text: The dot-com crash, housing crisis, and crypto winter all started when the bandwagon ran out of riders.

punchline.text: By the time everyone's talking about it, you're too late.

quiz.question: What drives the bandwagon effect in markets?
options: Rising adoption attracts more adopters regardless of fundamentals
Strong fundamentals always drive market prices
Government intervention pushes prices up

hook.text: A waiter brings a free mint with your check. Tips go up 3%. Two mints? Tips jump 14%.

buildup.text: Reciprocity means when someone gives us something, we feel obligated to give something back.

discovery.text: The Hare Krishnas gave free flowers at airports. People who accepted felt compelled to donate.

twist.text: The gift doesn't have to be valuable. Even small, unsolicited favors create a sense of debt.

climax.text: Free samples at grocery stores, free trials in SaaS, and free content in marketing all leverage this.

punchline.text: Give first. The return comes naturally.

quiz.question: Why do free samples increase purchases?
options: Receiving something free triggers a feeling of obligation to reciprocate
Free samples let customers test product quality
Stores legally require sampling before purchasing

hook.text: Milgram's experiment: ordinary people shocked strangers to dangerous levels because a doctor told them to.

buildup.text: Authority bias means we defer to experts and authority figures, sometimes without questioning them.

discovery.text: Uniforms, titles, and confident tone all trigger obedience â€” even when the authority is fake.

twist.text: Advertisers use actors in lab coats to sell toothpaste. We know they're actors and it still works.

climax.text: In organizations, junior staff suppress good ideas because a senior leader disagrees.

punchline.text: Credentials impress us. But credentials can be wrong.

quiz.question: What did Milgram's experiment demonstrate?
options: People obey authority figures even against their own moral judgment
People always resist unethical orders
Only certain personality types follow orders

hook.text: Can you beat the stock market? Classical economists say no. Behavioral economists say yes â€” sort of.

buildup.text: The efficient market hypothesis claims all available information is already reflected in prices.

discovery.text: If markets are efficient, no one can consistently outperform them. Index funds should win.

twist.text: But behavioral finance shows markets overshoot and undershoot due to fear, greed, and herd behavior.

climax.text: Both sides have a point. Markets are mostly efficient, but human irrationality creates pockets of opportunity.

punchline.text: Markets are smart. But they're still made of people.

quiz.question: What does the efficient market hypothesis claim?
options: All available information is already reflected in stock prices
Only insiders can profit from the market
Markets always go up over time

topics.title: Bubbles and Manias: From Tulips to Tech

hook.text: In 1637, a single tulip bulb in Holland sold for more than a house. Then the market collapsed overnight.

buildup.text: A bubble forms when asset prices soar far beyond intrinsic value, driven by speculation and euphoria.

discovery.text: Every bubble follows five stages: displacement, boom, euphoria, profit-taking, and panic.

twist.text: During euphoria, skeptics are mocked. 'This time is different' is the most dangerous phrase in finance.

climax.text: The dot-com bubble, 2008 housing crash, and crypto boom all followed the exact same pattern.

punchline.text: History doesn't repeat. But bubbles always rhyme.

quiz.question: What phrase is commonly heard during a financial bubble's euphoria phase?
options: 'This time is different'
'Sell everything now'
'Invest only in bonds'

hook.text: You won't touch your savings, but you'll blow a $500 tax refund in a weekend. It's all your money.

buildup.text: Mental accounting means we treat money differently depending on where it came from or what it's labeled.

discovery.text: Richard Thaler showed people are more reckless with 'found money' â€” bonuses, refunds, winnings.

twist.text: Casinos exploit this. Chips don't feel like real money, so gamblers bet more freely.

climax.text: Budgeting apps use mental accounting for good: labeling money makes people spend less carelessly.

punchline.text: A dollar is a dollar. But our brains disagree.

quiz.question: What is mental accounting?
options: Treating money differently based on its source or label
Keeping precise financial records
Using mental math for budgeting

hook.text: Investors sell winning stocks too early and hold losing stocks too long. Every study confirms it.

buildup.text: The disposition effect combines loss aversion and mental accounting into one costly investing mistake.

discovery.text: Selling winners feels good â€” you lock in a gain. Holding losers avoids the pain of admitting failure.

twist.text: The rational move is opposite: let winners run and cut losers fast. Emotions push us backward.

climax.text: Odean studied 10,000 brokerage accounts and found this pattern was nearly universal.

punchline.text: We sell our flowers and water our weeds.

quiz.question: What is the disposition effect?
options: Selling winners too early and holding losers too long
Always selling at a loss
Only buying stocks that are rising

hook.text: Would you rather have $100 today or $110 tomorrow? Most take the $100. But $100 in 30 days or $110 in 31? They wait.

buildup.text: Hyperbolic discounting means we massively overvalue immediate rewards compared to future ones.

discovery.text: This is why people skip retirement saving. The pleasure of spending now dwarfs the abstract future gain.

twist.text: The bias disappears with distance. We plan to start dieting on Monday but never on today.

climax.text: Commitment devices work: auto-transfer to savings, gym contracts, public pledges.

punchline.text: We're patient about the future. Just not about right now.

quiz.question: What is hyperbolic discounting?
options: Overvaluing immediate rewards relative to future ones
Discounting products based on demand curves
A pricing strategy for digital goods

hook.text: A fly etched inside a urinal at Amsterdam airport reduced spillage by 80%. Nobody was forced to aim.

buildup.text: A nudge changes behavior by altering the environment, not by restricting choice or adding incentives.

discovery.text: Thaler and Sunstein popularized the concept: make the desired behavior the easiest path.

twist.text: Nudges are invisible by design. If you notice the nudge, it's probably not working as intended.

climax.text: Cafeterias that put salads at eye level and desserts in the back increase healthy eating â€” no bans needed.

punchline.text: Don't tell people what to do. Make the right thing easy.

quiz.question: What makes a nudge different from a mandate?
options: It changes behavior without restricting freedom of choice
It uses financial penalties
It requires new legislation

hook.text: Sweden switched pension plans to opt-out. Enrollment jumped from 43% to 86% overnight.

buildup.text: Opt-in means you must actively choose. Opt-out means you're included unless you actively leave.

discovery.text: The difference is tiny on paper â€” one checkbox â€” but massive in behavior.

twist.text: GDPR made marketing emails opt-in across Europe. Newsletter signups cratered immediately.

climax.text: The power of default applies everywhere: insurance, donations, subscriptions, and privacy settings.

punchline.text: One checkbox can reshape an entire population's behavior.

quiz.question: Why does opt-out enrollment dramatically increase participation?
options: Most people accept the default and don't actively change it
People prefer being told what to do
Opt-out programs offer better benefits

hook.text: Can a government steer your choices while respecting your freedom? Thaler says yes â€” with careful design.

buildup.text: Libertarian paternalism means structuring choices so the best option is easiest, while keeping all options open.

discovery.text: It's paternalist because it guides. It's libertarian because you can always choose differently.

twist.text: Critics call it manipulation. Supporters call it good design. The debate is far from settled.

climax.text: The UK's Behavioral Insights Team saved billions using this approach on tax, health, and energy policy.

punchline.text: Design the choice. Don't remove it.

quiz.question: What defines libertarian paternalism?
options: Guiding choices while preserving freedom to choose otherwise
Mandating specific behaviors by law
Removing all choices to simplify decisions

hook.text: Dark patterns trick you into buying things you didn't want. That's behavioral economics weaponized.

buildup.text: Nudges can serve users or exploit them. The same psychology powers both helpful defaults and deceptive UX.

discovery.text: Amazon's one-click buy reduces friction for willing buyers. But it also catches impulsive spenders.

twist.text: Who decides what's a helpful nudge vs. manipulation? The designer, the user, or the regulator?

climax.text: The EU started banning dark patterns in 2023. The line between nudge and manipulation is becoming law.

punchline.text: The power to shape choices comes with the duty to use it well.

quiz.question: What is a 'dark pattern' in design?
options: A deceptive interface trick that manipulates users into unintended actions
A color scheme that reduces screen glare
An A/B testing method for dark-mode UIs
